PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

A. AIM OF QUESTIONNAIRES FOR THE DESIGN

It is difficult to answer a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Institute to five details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of our permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name MRS. CLARISSA L. BEAN (Mrs. Faircloth)

2. Your address 7313 GATEWAY BLVD S.E., Washington D.C.

3. Date 8-8-53

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   LINCOLNSHIRE ENGLAND

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   JOSEPH A HANDLEY

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   November 1905

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   May 10, 1903-1905 Winnipeg, Man. Canada

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   8 yrs old

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   My mother, a widow with three children took up a homestead at Dana, Sask.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    My brother Joseph Handley helped build the Grand Trunk Pacific R.R. in Sante from Winnipeg West
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They thought my poor mother was completely bereft of her senses, but we all ventured and proceeded to love the Saskatchewan.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With my Mother, Brother and Sister

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Train

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

We were first guests to use the Bruno, Sask Hotel—room was not quite completed upon our arrival—I slept in one of the children’s cribs belonging to the Hotel Prop. Mr & Mrs Schwinghammer—

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Bruno Hotel, Bruno, Sask—then to Mr John Young’s homestead, Bruno, Sask.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Dana, Sask

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Elbow, Sask—my step-father owned the Elbow, Sask Hotel—then to Nokomis Hotel in 1909—then to a farm at Elbow, Sask. 1910

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I was a child and living at home—
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Mr. Bert Marshall came with us from Winnipeg, Man.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Same time - except my brother, Joseph Handley took up homestead about 1904 or 5.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Yes - my sister and I walked over to a Galician family about 2 miles from home. They were bathing their live baby in a wooden tub hewn out of a big log - in this hot tub they kept putting snow in the water and the baby was splashing in the snow water. We had dinner there Galician style - cabbage, boiled potatoes, boiled salt pork. This was very good. The Galician bread was a dark bread and very delicious. On our way walking home we encountered one timber wolf. My sister and I were frightened to death and began to scream. I guess our screams frightened the wolf and he did not attack us.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

We visited friends, etc. by going on ox cart - drove several miles each way.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   We think our first car was an old Cadillac - 1911 or 1912. Simpson Say.
   We have the picture of it.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   Dad owned a Cadillac - 1912 or 1911

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Dana, Sask., 2½ miles away

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Continued there until we moved to Willow

29. How often did you shop in Willow?
   Almost once a month

30. When (if ever) did people go to town on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you fill your total purchases made by mail or in person?
   Not sure of it. It was built and we also bought

32. When did you first have a Simpson Say?
   Simpson Say

33. When you came to Saskatchewan permanently? Or did you make this decision?
   Yes - I left my family and came to the U.S.A. To Florida - I came with them
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   We think our first car was a Cadillac - 1911 or 1912 - Simpson says we have the picture of it.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   Dad owned a Cadillac - 1912 or 1911

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Dana, Sask., 2½ miles away

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Continued there until we moved to Elbow

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   About once a week - mostly Saturdays

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   Not sure of dates - T. Eaton Co., Ltd., Winnipeg. May was built and opened while we lived in Winnipeg. We also bought by mail from Simpson Co.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   Simpson Sask. 1912

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Yes - I left when my mother and step-father came to the U.S.A. To Florida - I came with them
Continued there until we moved to Ellwood.

I also had 2 wild coyotes which were given to me as puppies—they became very tame and the two coyotes and I were great pals—just like two dogs—I could cuddle and play with them—also had a tame crane and some small baby ducks—gophers etc. were also my playmates—had them in a cage—I could play with them—they would not run away.

To Florida—I came with...
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Mrs. Joseph Handley - Postmaster, Speedwell Park
My brother Joseph Handley
To 1942 or 1943 - The new Post Master at Fairholme Park

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

First family to own a piano in Danay and also at Baldwin Park - Bought it with two from Winnipeg Man

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Have old photograph of my brother and I taken with our ox team hitched to our wagons on the streets of Winnipeg, Man.

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon? (indicate your preference, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

(Son) Mr. Joseph A. Laarelto - Washington D.C., U.S.A. (Dry Operator)
(Grandson) Joseph A. Laarelto Jr.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West? It has made considerable progress both in farming, living conditions, schools, churches, roads etc. No comparison between today's progress with that of the pioneer days of 1906.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:
